content.rendered:
First observed in 1863, Cinco de Mayo is the celebration of the victory of Mexico over France in the Battle of Puebla the previous year. In the USA, the holiday was first celebrated in California and has become associated with Mexican-American culture.

The holiday grew in popularity when, in the 1980s, alcohol companies began to advertise the holiday. But there is more to Cinco de Mayo than beer, wine and tequila. And a good Cinco de Mayo party should have lots of food.

Molé is a key ingredient in several Mexican dishes. It is sauce that begins with chilis, tomato and spices. There are several variations, with at least one with chocolate added. Preparation depends on the style of molé that is being made.

Tamales are another iconic Mexican dish. Tamales are two separate recipes — the meat, which can be beef or pork — and the corn paste that the meat is cooked in. Usually the paste is spread into a dried corn husk, a small amount of meat is added, and the tamales are folded into the corn husk before steaming.

Fish Tacos became popular in the 50s and 60s in some costal areas in Mexico — around the same time that Cinco de Mayo was gaining popularity in the US. Fish tacos are similar to other tacos, with the exception of the meat used. And you can make them as simple or as complex as you like.

One other thing. If you want to host a Cinco de Mayo party, don’t forget the music. If you can’t find a local radio station with Mexican music, you should be able to find some online and, likely, on a smartphone. And don’t forget the guacamole.

Need help figuring out what to make? Here are some cookbooks that you can download from Amazon.
